videoData.title: A moving song from women in prison for life
videoData.socialTitle: A moving song from women in prison for life

learnModules.blurb: Three years after their TED performance, an update on the Lady Lifers.
learnModules.headline: "Muncy state prison's lady lifers talk of redemption"

nodes.whoTheyAre: A life sentence in Pennsylvania means exactly that; there is no possibility of parole. These women, all of whom have served decades in prison, sing about their lives on the inside.
nodes.whyListen:
“I’m a woman, I’m a grandmother, I’m a daughter, I have a son,” sings Brenda Watkins, lead vocalist for The Lady Lifers. “I’m not an angel, I’m not the devil. I came to jail when I was so young.”

The Lady Lifers are a chorus of women serving life sentences in Muncy State Prison in Pennsylvania. While they are often known by their inmate numbers, they also have names: Brenda Watkins, Dannielle Hadley, Debra Lee Brown, Theresa Battles, Diane Metzger, Thelma Nichols, Joann Butler, Lena Brown, Trina Garnett, Naomi Blount. Together, they sing about their hopes and fears, including the very real possibility that they may die alone in prison.

The words to their song “This is Not My Home” by Howard Woodring. Music by Naomi Blount.

videoData.description: The ten women in this chorus have all been sentenced to life in prison. They share a moving song about their experiences — one that reveals their hopes, regrets and fears. "I'm not an angel," sings one, "but I'm not the devil." Filmed at an independent TEDx event inside Muncy State Prison, it's a rare and poignant look inside the world of people imprisoned with no hope of parole. (Note: The prison's Office of Victim Advocacy has ensured that victims were treated fairly and respectfully around this TEDx event.)
videoData.socialDescription: The ten women in this chorus have all been sentenced to life in prison. They share a moving song about their experiences — one that reveals their hopes, regrets and fears. "I'm not an angel," sings one, "but I'm not the devil." Filmed at an independent TEDx event inside Muncy State Prison, it's a rare and poignant look inside the world of people imprisoned with no hope of parole. (Note: The prison's Office of Victim Advocacy has ensured that victims were treated fairly and respectfully around this TEDx event.)

cues.text:
Dannielle Hadley: Life
in Pennsylvania means just that:
life without the possibility of parole.

which has only been granted
to two women since 1989,
Our song, "This Is Not Our Home,"

while doing life without
the possibility of parole.
while I do life without parole.

I am a prisoner
for the wrong I've done.
Dream of freedom, hope for mercy.
because if I cry I'd give in to fear.
I must be strong, have to hold on.

I am a prisoner
for the wrong I've done.

I'm doing time here.
This is not my home.
Dream of freedom, hope for mercy.
I'm not saying that I'm not guilty,
I'm not saying that I shouldn't pay.
All I'm asking is for forgiveness.
Gotta have hope I'll be free someday.
Is there a place for me

Will they ever know or care
that I'm chained?

Is there redemption for the sin
of my younger days?

I am a prisoner
for the wrong I've done.

I'm doing time here.
This is not my home.
Dream of freedom, hope for mercy.
I'm known to you as Inmate 008106.

I was born and raised
in Hoffman, North Carolina.

I was born and raised
in Philadelphia, P.A.

I was born and raised
in Philadelphia, P.A,
and this is not my home.
and this is not my home.

and I was born and raised in Philadelphia.

I've been incarcerated for 39
and one half years.
My name is Diane Hamill Metzger.
and this is not my home.

and I was born and raised
in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania,
and this is not my home.
Born and raised in Chester, Pennsylvania,
and this is not my home.
